thread.title: Quade Cooper beats Jack McInnes before Mundine-Green fight
thread.title_full: Quade Cooper beats Jack McInnes before Mundine-Green fight | Daily Mail Online

author: Max Margan For Daily Mail Australia
title: Quade Cooper beats Jack McInnes before Mundine-Green fight

organizations.name: living end's prisoner of society cooper

text:
Quade Cooper has won his third professional fight against a boxer who has been widely ridiculed for his apparent lack of fitness.
Wallabies and Queensland Reds star Cooper, 28, faced relatively unknown brawler Jack McInnes, 22, at the Adelaide Oval on Friday night.
The undercard bout for the highly-anticipated Anthony Mundine-Danny Green fight was, as many pundits expected, a one-sided affair.
Scroll down for video
Quade Cooper has won his third professional fight against a boxer who has been widely ridiculed for his apparent lack of fitness
Wallabies and Queensland Reds star Cooper, 28, faced relatively unknown brawler Jack McInnes, 22, at the Adelaide Oval on Friday night
Cooper now has three consecutive wins in his pro career - all by knockout
Cooper (L) and Jack McInnes (R) fight during their bout at Adelaide Oval on Friday night
Cooper, a strong favourite on all betting markets, was relentless from the outset, nearly flooring his opponent in the opening 10 seconds of the bout.
The rugby union star landed blow-after-blow in the opening round, with one right-left combination drawing a broad smile from his opponent.
The referee called off the fight after McInnes was floored mid-way through the second round, with blood pouring from his nose.
McInnes had also been knocked out in his previous two pro boxing fights
McInnes was felled by several consecutive head punches from Cooper
The undercard bout for the highly-anticipated Anthony Mundine-Danny Green fight was, as many pundits expected, a one-sided affair
Cooper's speed an agility proved too much for McInnes, who smiled for much of the bout
Cooper landed blow-after blow in the opening round
Cooper now has three consecutive wins in his pro career - all by knockout - after out-muscling an opponent more renowned for his mixed martial arts skills.
McInnes, who had also been knocked out in his previous two pro boxing fights, was felled by several consecutive head punches from Cooper, who will now return to preseason rugby training with the Reds.
Prior to the bout, questions were raised about the fitness of McInnes, who boasts 55 professional fights across Muay Thai, boxing and cage fighting.
Prior to fight, questions were raised about the fitness of 22-year-old McInnes
Cooper now boasts three wins from his three professional boxing bouts
The 22-year-old made his way to the ring to the tune of The Living End's Prisoner of Society
Cooper, 28, never looked troubled as he made light work of his younger opponent
Cooper out-muscled his opponent who is more renowned for his mixed martial arts skills
Wallabies star Cooper (left) stepped into the ring with little-known McInnes at the Adelaide Oval on Friday night
Fans flocked to the Adelaide Oval on Friday night ahead of the highly-anticipated boxing match between Anthony Mundine and Danny Green
After images emerged from the official weigh-in, social media users were quick to point out that the 22-year-old was not exactly in top shape for the cruiserweight battle.
'Good to see Quade Cooper's opponent looking in good nick,' one joked, while another asked: 'Anyone know why Quade Cooper is fighting the fat kid from Hey Dad?'
Ahead of the bout, McInnes defended himself against the social media backlash by claiming anything could happen.
McInnes (pictured in 2013) claims to have 55 fights under his belt across Muay Thai kickboxing, boxing and cage fighting
The bout was Coopers third professional fight - on the undercard of Friday night's Mundine-Green bout. Above, he is seen in action during his fight against Barry Dunnett in their cruiserweight fight in 2013
McInnes said prior to the fight: 'I'm confident - anything can happen, it only takes one punch'
Prior to the fight, questions were raised on social media about the fitness of McInnes
'I'm confident - anything can happen, it only takes one punch. This will still be my last fight,' he told the Sunshine Coast Daily.
On Thursday, Cooper said it takes courage for sportsmen from non-boxing backgrounds to step into the ring.
'All of the guys who are athletes and sportsmen who have basically had the courage to step in the ring, there's a massive target on us,' he said.
'Because we're already athletes and we're already professionals in a different field, people just expect us to be world champions overnight.
'But it's a long process and something I have a lot of respect for everybody who has been able to step in the ring and have the opportunity to be a boxer.'
Cooper said his fight in Adelaide came with the blessing of his rugby club, the Queensland Reds.
McInnes, 22, lost his only two previous professional boxing fights
Cooper said his fight in Adelaide came with the blessing of his rugby club, the Queensland Reds
Cooper celebrates winning his fight against Barry Dunnett in their cruiserweight fight at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre in 2013
'It's great to have the support of our coach and the club as well to be able to do something like this,' he said.
'Very rarely would a sportsman get the opportunity to chase something else that they enjoy as well, especially in the lead-up to the season.
'So I'm grateful for the support there and hopefully I can continue to do it more often.'
Cooper, whose last pro fight before Friday was in January 2014, said he would continue juggling boxing with rugby - but for how long remained unknown.
'It's difficult but it's a challenge that I enjoy,' he said.
'If I didn't enjoy doing it, I wouldn't put myself through the immense training, the physical effort, because sometimes after footy training you feel a bit flat and you don't really want to do more physical work.
'But because I enjoy it so much, I find the energy.
'I haven't looked too far ahead ... when the enjoyment factor leaves, then you have got to look at where you are as an athlete and what the future holds.'
The undercard bout for the highly-anticipated Anthony Mundine and Danny Green fight was, as expected, a one-sided affair
